articles.title: July '79
articles.summary: This document outlines the schedule of events for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for July, August, and early September 1979, including various indoor and outdoor star parties, board meetings, and general meetings. Key events include the annual officers' installation picnic, the 10th anniversary of the Moon landing, and details for ASTRO-NORTHWEST '79, a joint national astronomy convention. The document also lists the SJAA officers for the 1979-80 term.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The article discusses the arrival of summer and the start of star party season, detailing upcoming club events at Fremont Peak and Sanborn Canyon Park, including an SJAA picnic. It also reports on a successful star party at Henry Coe State Park with good Skylab observations and covers recent club administration news such as board elections, editor's notes and apologies, and updates on membership and merchandise.

articles.title: Address Changes
articles.summary: This document lists recent address changes for two individuals: Norm Wild, who moved from San Jose to Cupertino, and Richard Glasspool, whose updated Cupertino address is also provided.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: The article describes a current 'comet drought' with very few new comet discoveries or recoveries this year. However, it highlights Comet Meier (1978f) as an exception, noting its current visibility in the morning sky and providing an ephemeris with its projected right ascension, declination, and magnitude from June to August as it leaves the inner Solar System.

articles.title: Makers Conference
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association received an award at the Makers Conference. This recognition was specifically for their innovative "System Concept & Unique Electronics," with Cliff Holms and Daf Michael also noted in relation to the award.

articles.title: Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference --SJAA Style
articles.summary: The article recounts the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) highly successful trip to the Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference (RTMC) at Big Bear, with over 20 members attending. Key activities included setting up camp, observing, attending talks, and demonstrating the club's new television camera. A major highlight was the club receiving a certificate of merit for their innovative TV camera demonstration, marking the first time an entire club was recognized at the RTMC.

articles.title: What I Did On February 26, 1979
articles.summary: Don Machholz recounts his meticulously planned attempt to observe the total solar eclipse on February 26, 1979, near Goldendale, Washington, with a group using extensive equipment for photography and comet hunting. Despite initial promising conditions and a well-chosen site, clouds unexpectedly moved in just before totality, largely obscuring the main event. Although they missed the full spectacle, the group noted atmospheric effects and Machholz reflects on lessons learned for future eclipse expeditions.

articles.title: On The Psychophysiological Factors Associated With A Lunar Occultation Of The Nearest Star On 26 Feb 79
articles.summary: This satirical article from the "Institute of Sibling Rivalry" humorously analyzes the "psychophysiological factors" and "confusing and disoriented" behaviors of Homo sapiens during solar eclipses, despite its title referring to a lunar occultation. It categorizes human reactions into five groups—Primitives, Technocrats, Innocent Civilians, Miscellaneous, and Others—describing their often irrational and bizarre behaviors, from elaborate rituals to complete indifference. The piece uses fictional examples and a comedic tone to critique various human responses to astronomical events.

articles.title: Conclusions
articles.summary: The article details a surprising turn of events where Technocrats proved ineffectual during a celestial phenomenon, merely observing the 'darkening Sun'. In stark contrast, Primitives, typically stereotyped as passive, actively and successfully responded to the event by employing traditional methods to 'scare away' what they perceived as a dragon, thereby 'preserving the Sun' and validating their beliefs.

articles.title: References:
articles.summary: The article presents a mix of satirical references, including a humorous take on securing research funding by loosely associating it with solar eclipses and medical research, and a 'Question of the Month.' This question prompts club members to share their diverse memories of where they were on 'July 20, 1962,' mostly recalling watching a significant, 'unbelievable' space event on television, strongly implying the Apollo 11 Moon landing despite the date discrepancy.

articles.title: And ten years later.....
articles.summary: This article, reprinted from 1979, emphasizes the critical importance of continuing space exploration as a defining challenge of our era. It warns against abandoning this 'spirit of adventure,' arguing that retreating from space would risk national progress, deny our historical capabilities, and diminish the forward thrust of human intelligence.

articles.title: Question of the Month for August:
articles.summary: This article presents August's 'Question of the Month,' asking readers what they would do with unlimited access to a 200-inch telescope under perfect seeing conditions. It also includes a humorous remark and a couple of seemingly unrelated quotes.

articles.title: The Dr. A.B. Gregory Memorial Award
articles.summary: The article announces the establishment of the Dr. A.B. Gregory Memorial Award, an annual plaque to be presented by the SJAA to a club member. This award recognizes outstanding contribution of time and effort in encouraging and assisting interests in amateur astronomy, embodying Dr. Gregory's spirit and enthusiasm. The proposal details the nomination and selection process, funding through donations, and aims for the first presentation at the July 1980 general meeting, with initial funding from Norm Neinchel and Bob Fingerhut.

articles.title: AVAILABLE PUBLICATIONS
articles.summary: The article lists astronomical publications available through a club at discounted prices (10-45% off Sky Publishing rates). Members can order these books and bulletins from the club treasurer, with ordering contacts changing from Bob Fingerhut (until July 15) to Cathy Pinheiro (after July 15).

articles.title: FOR SALE
articles.summary: This article is a classified advertisement for an Edmund Scientific 4.25-inch reflector telescope with a 45-inch focal length (f/10.9) and a cast aluminum equatorial mount. It includes a 6x finder scope, three eyepieces, a Barlow lens, an instruction book, and star maps, all described as being in mint condition. The seller, M.R. Johnston, is asking $260 for the telescope, which has a replacement cost of approximately $360.

articles.title: SKY WORD #3
articles.summary: This document presents "SKY WORD #3," a word puzzle created by Fred Braniff. The puzzle features a grid filled with letters, spelling out various astronomy-related terms, constellations, and historical figures. It appears to be an engaging and educational activity for readers interested in astronomy.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: The article, written by club president Gerry Rattley, begins with a plea for volunteers to manage refreshments and contribute a 'get to know your fellow club members' column to the bulletin, warning of refreshment cessation if no one steps forward. It then presents a questionnaire for members to provide feedback on general meetings (location, programs, schedule, day), indoor and outdoor star parties (structure, participation, location preferences), and the club bulletin, requesting their input to be returned to the Board of Directors.

articles.title: FAINT FUZZY NOTHINGS, a Deep-Sky Column by Gerry Rattley
articles.summary: Gerry Rattley's "FAINT FUZZY NOTHINGS" column outlines observing opportunities for the upcoming New Moon period, marking the transition from viewing distant galaxies to focusing on the Northern Milky Way Halo's globular clusters. It proposes an observing project to compare globular clusters, introduces NGC 5897 as the "Turkey of the Month" challenge object, and highlights Σ Scorpii as the visual binary of the month, encouraging reader participation and skill improvement.

articles.title: Photo Gallery
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) attended an event at Camp Oakes near Big Bear City, California, where their van caravan was present and they entered a TV camera in a telescope competition. Pete Manly, the project manager for the IBM-funded camera, explained its features to judges and passers-by, ultimately winning an award and demonstrating it on C-8 and 18-inch telescopes.
